title: Kashif Siddiqi heads to Real Kashmir in hope of uniting people: 'Football can save lives - I just want to bring some hope'
text:
In a few days, Kashif Siddiqi will fly out with his football boots to join a new club on loan. Nothing unusual in that, except the Oxford United defender is leaving the cosy environs of League One for Real Kashmir, in the world’s most militarised and politically sensitive territory.

The appeal of moving to a war zone - 800,000 soldiers are currently stationed in Kashmir - may be lost on most, but for Siddiqi, this transfer is about far more than football.

“It’s a great story to show that it doesn’t matter where you have come from, what your background or religion is, football transcends all of that,” Siddiqi says, as we chat at Oxford's Kassam Stadium shortly before his departure. “Over the last couple of years especially I’ve been thinking about how I can do more.

"I see myself turning from a footballer to a diplomat. I feel sport has so much more to offer to the world but people are not understanding that and I want to stand up and go and show I’m walking the walk.

"Football touches billions of people but what is its influence to the world’s most pressing issues? It could do so much. Cristiano Ronaldo has more followers on social media than most countries have people. It’s unbelievable. That power alone. I know it’s harnessed commercially but how is it harnessed in a social impact way? Hardly at all.”
description: In a few days, Kashif Siddiqi will fly out with his football boots to join a new club on loan.
